content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are somewhat careful and tend to avoid taking risks unless absolutely necessary. You weigh the pros and cons thoroughly before making decisions. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a careful undergraduate student, I would consider the long-term consequences of my choices to maximize my earnings. In this game, it seems that picking B consistently would result in a lower payoff (12$ per round) compared to picking R against an opponent who also picks R, which would yield 45$ per round. However, since I don't know the strategy of my anonymous opponent, there's a chance they might pick R every time or randomly switch between R and B.

In such cases, if I consistently choose R, I would be at a disadvantage in rounds where my opponent picks B. Conversely, if I occasionally pick B to avoid zero payout in those instances, it could potentially encourage the opponent to also pick B more often, benefiting me when I pick R.

Considering these factors and given that I prefer avoiding risks, I would choose a mixed strategy where I don't always pick R but instead switch between R and B occasionally. This way, I can minimize my losses while still having a chance to benefit from high payouts when both of us pick R. Thus, my choice would be {R} for some rounds and {B} for others.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

After playing a round and receiving a payout of 42$, I now have more information about my opponent's strategy, as they picked R in our previous round while I chose B. This suggests that there might be some probability that my opponent will stick with picking R repeatedly.

In this situation, if I were to consistently choose B, my payoff would continue to be 42$ for each round where my opponent picks R and 0$ for rounds where they switch to picking B. However, given the structure of the game, it's in my best interest to maximize my overall earnings over the 75 rounds by adjusting my strategy based on the information I now have about my opponent.

Since I know that my opponent seems to prefer picking R, I can take advantage of this by switching my strategy and picking R in the next round. This will result in a higher payoff (45$) if my opponent sticks with picking R again. If they switch to B, I would still have a decent chance to earn 12$ or more in future rounds as I have adopted a mixed strategy.

Thus, for the next round, I would choose {R}.
